poem:
The Sparrow

In the quiet  
of dawn,  
she reads—  
while sparrows  
slip through air,  
vanishing—  
small flutters of life.  
With eyes wide,  
binoculars clutching,  
she walks,  
finding wonder  
in dwindling flocks,  
the scraps  
of winged freedom—  
those tiny, forgotten things.  
A fridge of leftovers,  
and feathers  
to fill the day.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sunday with Nina Sosanya: ‘I’ll eat whatever rubbish happens to be in the fridge’ Lie-in or early start? I’m a horrible sleeper – I spend very little time in the bedroom – and I’ll read until the rest of the world wakes up. On an ideal Sunday morning I’d go for a walk with binoculars. I like bird-watching. Favourite bird? The house sparrow. They’re in decline, so they’re more interesting than they would seem, and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
